X have the honour to be, Sir, Your moat obedient eervant, / I n r* • v • o • , Officiating Political Resident in the Persian Gulfa A D.T. Telegram Dated 14th February 1914. O.CU Bush ire. Kindly deliver following to Captain Dirdwood - deeply regret to hear sad news. Drey c/o G.Q. FaoDelhi, March 4 A press communique issued in the Foreign Denartment states that the last mail from the Persian Gul* brought full particulars of the unfortunate accident which caused the death of Mr. J.G.Lorimer, the officiting Resident at Eushire. On the morning of Sunday, February 8th, Mr. Lorimer after conversing with His Excellency the Governor o** Bu- shire on the telephone, left his office in which two of his assistants were working and went upstairs to his dressing room to ascertain the exact calibre of his automatic pistol as he wished to order some more cartridges from Bombay by the outward mail which left Bushire that day. He did not return to the office and eventually a search was made for him in connection with some oapers which required bis sig nature. He was found lying dead on the floor of his room. It was evident that Mr. Lorimer, in examining the pistol had pulled the trigger and discharged a last cartridge which had been overlooked in the magazine. The Residency Surgeon Major S. Hunt, I.M.S., who held the medical examination found that the bullet had entered the stomach and passed right through the body to the spine injuring the great blood vessels in its course. The shock in Major Hunt’s opinion, must have caused immediate loss of conciousness for the expression of the face was calm and peaceful, and death speedily followed from syncope. Ihe necessary enquiry was held by Caotain R.L.Birdwood, First Assistant to the Resident, Major S.Hunt, Residency Surgeon, Captain J.S.Crosthwaite,I.A., and Lieu tenant P.G.Loch, 2nd Assistant and their formal opinion was recorded, to the effect that Mr. Lofrimer met his death from wounds caused by the accidental discharge of’ an au tomatic pistol. Ihe funeral took place on the following day, February 9th. By the courtesy of the Senior Nayal Officer and the Officer- 7 ® / Officer Ooinmandlng the troops at Bushlre, a firing r^arty nadiers, and by the men of that Regiment. The coffin T vae drawn to the cemetery, preceded by the Residency escort and also at the special request Monsieur Loiko, the acting Russian Consul-General, by the Husain Cossac r Con sular Guard. The funeral ceremony was attended by His Ex cellency the Governor and the local authorities, the Con sular Corps, the whole of the European community as well as by a large number of the local i/ersian inhabitants who thus testified to the universal respect felt by all members of the community towards the deceased and the great popular ity he had earned during the short period of his incumb ency. Messages of sympathy were received by the British Legation at Tehran fro™ the Persian Government and from the French and German Ministers. of Bluejackets and Marines was landed ^rom H.M.S. w Fox w and the route was lined by the 10 o ad (King Edward f s Own) Gre-Buehire, Maroh 1914. a?o The ::5 olitieal Agent, K. u .v ait. Have heen appointed here as Officer on Special duty vice Knox and assumed charge on 19th. Bepeated to Kuwait hy post. Bushire, 20th April 1915. Trevor £— 4 -To The Political Agent, K o w e i t. Sir, I am directed to inform you tnat the Government of India have decided that while Major Trevor is employed on special duty and until further orders his designation should be Deputy Political Resident in the Persian Gulf. I I have the honour to be, Sir, Your most obedient servant, >1.Captain, First Assistant Resident. // & t * r-l f ^ h ' ClU/LLThe Residency, 25th November 1917. As you know I have been troubled for some time by a bad throat and husky voice. When I was at Bagdad I interviewed the throat specialists and the Consulting physician and they decided that the cause of the trouble was a strained heart, and ordered me off to England for complete rest. I am therefore sailing on the 20th by the S.S. 'Chakla', and write this to say good bye. It is not absolutely certain yet who will succeed me, but at present it looks as if Bill of the Indian Civil Service, who was First Assistant here and acting Consul at Shiraz some years ago would do so. For the present however Rae will carry on. Lieut-Col. R. A.E.Hamilton, I.A., Political Agent Koweitof 1935 ho. Britiah Residency and Consulate-Generalf Bushire, the 1st goveraber 1^29. 28th Janiadi al AvAval ,1548 His Excellency Shaikh Ahmed bin Subah,C.S # I.,C.I .IC., Ruler of Kuwait* A*C * I shall be handing over charge of this Residency to Lt.Colonel Biscog on the 8th November and then I shall go to England for leave* I had hoped to be able to pay Kuwait one more visit before leaving the Gulf but it has been impossible to manage it. Perhaps I may return some day in the future and meet you again* I am writing to wish you good bye and to thank you for the sincere and friendly manner in which you have carried out the wishes of His Majesty’s Government throughout the difficult days of the past summer. I am sure that you will be equally steadfast in the still more difficult days that may come in the near future* You will find in our mutual friend Colonel Dickson a wise adviser* whose counsel I am sure you will continue to accept in all important matters* U.E. Squadron, Basra. ^From The Political Agent, Kumit. To His Excellency The Ruler Of Kuwait. After compliments, I have the honour to inform your Excellency that the Hon f hle Lt. Col. T.C. Fowls, C.B.E., is proceeding to the United Kingdom by air on the 20th July 1933 on 3 months’ leave, and that Lt-Col. G.Loch will act for him during his absence. To Hi a Highness Shaikh Sir Ahmad al Jabir as Sabah, } • - • I • h # , C . b • I • , hiler of Kuwait. h.y esteeiaed friend, I was sorry that Your Highness was unable to come to the aerodrome on ! onday, when I passed through Kuwait as it deprived me of the pleasure of seeing you. (?.d % Political Resident in the Persian Gulf# ?ABDULLA MULLA SALEH / k'rwATT 8th Novem'ber, 1 My dear Iyer, I am enclosing herewith the letter of which I spoke £o you last night, and hope you will submit it to P.A. for his perusal. With my best wishes.(COPY) /S-J Ko.C-457 of1941 Dated 26th Cctoher 1f4-1 To His Highness Shaikh Sir.Ahmed Al-Jabir As-Subah, K.C.I.E. C.S.I., Ruler of Kuwait Kuwait. My esteemed friend, I have the honour to inform Jfour Highness that the Government of India are appointing me to the Middle East 'Var Council at Cairo and that during my absence Lieut. Colonel W.R. Hay, C.I.E., will officiate for me. I expect to hand over charge of the Residency at Delhi on 1st November 1541, corresponding to the 11th Shawwal 1360, and then will proceed to Egypt. I regret very much that I shall not have the opportunity of seeing your Highness this winter as I hoped and in saying farewell to you I beg to express my sincere hope for your prosperity and long life. I remdin with much consideration. , ; Your Highness sincere friend. (Sd)•••»••• Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Eushire.fig? in ^ As, Kuwait.8th October,1$41 After Complimets; I have the honour to receive with thanks your kind letter No.C-457 of 26th October 1f41 in which you infomred me of your appointement to the Middle East S T ar Council at Cairo and about Ycur Excellency’s replacement to officiate during your absence. I ardently wish you all success with glory and wish to see you again in the best of health and prosperity. I was hoping to have a chance of metting Your Excellency before your departure, but in such circumstances as at present, duty is above everything, for the success of vihich cause we are all prepared to serve to our utmost. In conclusion, I wish that success will follow with you in your departure as well as in the performance of ycur duty.(< J'/p /*/'<//// (s (JJ Telegram From To No. GTC Political Resident, Bahrain. December, 1949. fUf) Appoinlment of British Resilient in Cyrennien Sir, I have to inform you that, consequent upon the establishment in Cyrenaica of a Cyrenaican Government with reponsibility over internal affairs, the title of “ Chief Administrator ” was by Order in Council altered to “British Resident” as from 28th October, 1949. 2. I have therefore to request that future correspondence be addressed to the British Resident, British Residency, Benghazi, Cyrenaica. 3. A similar circular has been addressed to His Majesty’s Representative (as No. 0140). I am, ^ Sir, Your obedient Servant, C. R. ATTLEE. His Majesty’s Consular Officers 15812 37925a

location.physicalLocation: British Library: India Office Records and Private Papers

titleInfo.title: ‘Establishment. No. I/12 Appointments and Changes in the Political Residents & Agents in the Persian Gulf, and Secretaries, Bushire, & of the Govt. of India. and Others.’

physicalDescription.extent: The file’s contents are arranged in approximate chronological order, from the earliest item at the front to the latest at the end. The file notes at the end of the file (ff 189-191) mirror the chronological arrangement, but only relate to correspondence covering the period November 1941 to the file’s end date.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the last folio with 191; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located at the top right corner of the recto side of each folio.An additional mixed foliation sequence is present in parallel between ff 2-188; these numbers are also written in pencil, and, where circled, are crossed through.

mods.abstract: Correspondence relating to the departure (either permanently or on temporary leave) of current, and the arrival of new incumbents, to the post of Political Resident and Consulate General in the Persian Gulf. The file includes:circulars issued by the Political Resident to Political Agents and Officers in the Persian Gulf and in Persia [Iran], informing them of changes to the post of Political Resident;correspondence sent from the Political Agent at Kuwait to the Ruler of Kuwait [Shaikh Aḥmad al-Jābir Āl Ṣabāḥ], informing of changes to the post of Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, with the Ruler of Kuwait’s replies. Copies of letters sent to the Ruler of Kuwait are in Arabic. All replies from the Ruler are in Arabic, with most being accompanied by an English translation;covering letters sent between the Ruler of Kuwait and the Political Agent at Kuwait, and the Political Agent and Political Resident, with forwarded correspondence of diplomatic etiquette exchanged between the Ruler of Kuwait and the Political Resident;a copy of a press communiqué issued on the event of the death of the Political Resident John Gordon Lorimer, in 1914 (ff 7-8).Later correspondence in the file reports on changes to the posts of Secretary to the Political Resident in the Persian Gulf, Political Agent at Bahrain, and Political Agent and British Consul at Muscat.
